Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 4cee35e72cc593f7d407c110ed8c19afb78d279c
More details needed here on why this needs to be compile time configurable.  I would've expected this to use the mapper.

This is nowhere near enough detail, and as written, could apply to just about any patch within bmcweb.  What did you test?  Please include enough detail that someone could verify the function of the same.
Removed this in favor of not auto-expanding. We wont need it.
You want all users (including read only users) to have access to the ROT collections?  That seems different than I would expect, please take a look.

For new code, please write these as non-lambda so they're unit testable, and reduce function scope.  I realize the above is a lambda, but we're going through a transition trying to move to more normal looking callbacks.

This is generally not how we build collections in redfish/bmcweb;  Most of the time we use the mapper to determine what ROTs exist in the system (take a look at the utility classes for building collections).
Status is generally not an array, but you're treating it like one here.
I think we dont need description. Name would do.
If you're trying to make this look like a Redfish resource type, Description is generally required.  If you're not, I'm really surprised we'd take the time to do odata.
Nothing upstream currently requires that field. Will add once we have a usecase for it.

Sorry to key on this, but either:

A. we're following the odata/redfish resource spec, in which case description I believe is required by the schemas as they're written in this patch.
B. We don't have a need to follow the odata spec, so the schema definitions can be removed to save the complexity of writing them, and having them be incorrect/not followed.

I'm fine with either approach, but a middle ground of "we write odata schemas, but them don't follow them" I don't think is in our best interest here, as it largely defeats the purpose of writing down the schema in the first place.
That's fair. I added the description now.

Please don't combine initializer list initialization and operator[] initialization.  It makes the code hard to read.  YOu probably want

jsonValue["Actions"]["#RootOfTrust.SendCommand"]["target"] = ...
You should be using the rotId as some piece of the dbus path, so that if the object doesn't exist, dbus can return an error.
Shouldn't we be accepting this comment by std::vector<uint8_t>?  Inside these APIs, using hex strings are fairly rare (I can't think of any).

Vidya proposed encoding the host command bytes in a hex string (2-char per byte). 

Is there a convention in OpenBMC for encoding bytes over the wire? base64 is more efficient; hex encoding is easier to visual parse during debug, etc.

The convention is "don't" ie, structure your data structures in ways that are parsable in the tree 😊

We do have other places where we encode a json payload as a separate URI path, then just set the content-type appropriately there (see any of the dump routes for that) but that doesn't  seem great either.

Hex encoding is also not super friendly for parsing in our usecases but it helps us with
a) debugging things faster
b) achieve parity with how we currently represent things on the gsys methods.

Opting for hex, because the strings are also not very large. ~100 bytes.
Is it worth mentioning hoth commands here? The commands aren't completely arbitrary.
Is this still needed if we're going with RootOfTrust/RootOfTrustCollection?
Can you get added to your company's CI group?
I am confused, I see some of these same changes at a pervious review: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/50059/11/include/google/google_service_root.hpp ?

Ah. Please consider that PR dropped. 
The person left the position so it's on me to carry this 😊

The idea is largely the same. Added unit tests and some discovery mechanisms in this iteration.

Add Google Copyright for this?

Also auto format for all files in this change

> Add Google Copyright for this?


We generally don't add copyrights to individual files.  They have no effect, as technically all this code is owned by LF openbmc.

Sorry for the thrash, but please remove.

nit: different styles (snake_case and camelCase) here and elsewhere in this change
bmcweb uses mostly camelCase.

Some nits from CodeChecker:

include/google/dbus_utils.hpp @ Line 48
cppcoreguidelines-special-member-functions
class 'ObjectMapperInterface' defines a default destructor but does not define a copy constructor, a copy assignment operator, a move constructor or a move assignment operator

Same for HothInterface and RedfishUtilWrapper

But I guess these are not real concerns here.

Some nits from the CodeChecker:

misc-definitions-in-headers
variable 'obj_mapper' defined in a header file; variable definitions in header files can lead to ODR violations

Same for rf_utils and hoth_iface.

Since this is not enforced by the CI it is probably okay for now.

nitpick/future thing.  There are reviews in process to deprecate using = {} syntax for nlohmann as it leads to more code.

Just do 

asyncResp->res.jsonValue["RootOfTrustCollection"]["@odata.id"]
combine since `path` is not sued anywhere else.
Just some nits from the CodeChecker

if it is all public, then this should just be a struct.

also, toDbusMethodAddr can be a constructor instead of having this method.

these follow the Google C++ sytle, but I think we want it to follow OpenBMC style in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#constants.

Up to Ed.
I prefer Google C++ style of constants easy to follow but given openBMC project, I'm ok to change either way.
You should be using the OpenBMC style guide since this code lives in OpenBMC

is this the only way to do this?

I don't think we really want global variable like this.

I think normally we want to create a new class that inherient AsyncResp and have the variables in there like with SensorAsyncResp https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/sensors.hpp#L160

LGTM. Thanks for pointing this.
I looked at the pattern for dbus_singleton.hpp where there is one instance of systemBus and thought it is standard/applicable.

We can totally avoid global variables as you point out.
Should this be moved to the main dbus_utils.hpp since it isn't specific to Google?

Moving it to dbus_utility.hpp is raising a lot of dependency issues, because GetSubTreeType is defined in openbmc_dbus_rest.hpp and to resolve them I'd need to touch upwards of a dozen files.

I'd like to keep this PR focussed on google usecase and clean up later. Added a TODO for the same.

In retrospect, seems like most other redfish classes like Chassis each have their own way of dealing with ObjectMapper and it would have been nicer if there was a common way of interacting with it like in my PR. Seems like a missed opportunity. Well, hopefully we will get to it at some point.

We have two competing patches for the "abstract dbus to unit test it" approach.  Can you discuss with the Heinz (on discord, mailing list, or in gerrit review) and come up with something that meets both of your needs?

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/52693

You're both essentially doing the same thing, in two radically different ways. FWIW, my read is, the 52693 approach is a lot less code, but less type safe, so we need to decide what tradeoffs are important to us.

As discussed offline, since we are blocked on this, I've split the test logic into a separate PR. 
I would revisit the approach later this month.
std::string_view please, as it's generally safer, and doesn't need checked for nullptr.  With that said, I wonder if this should really just be an owning copy (std::string).  thoughts?

Why do we need a custom AsyncResp object here?  Generally the reason for declaring an AsyncResp is to do "work" once all things are complete, but this class isn't actually doing any work at the end, so I'm not really sure why it exists?

This provides a way for us to pass in either mocks of various dbus objects or the real ones without having 

Approach copied from https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/sensors.hpp#L160

based on inputs from Willy.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/52222/13..15/include/google/google_service_root.hpp#b50
Please try to avoid forward declaring methods like this.  It generally implies that your code needs reorganized into different files.

We are creating a static const object here. Not invoking a method. 
Same as other object creations below?
This is going to malloc on startup and consume memory for the life of the program.  Please use constexpr std::array.
Oh. This looks like its not even useful.
nit, please just call it "req", if only for consistency.

Please don't use auto in this way.  It obfuscates the type.

https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Type_deduction
Are you sure this is the privilege level you want?  Do we need a specific privilege level for interacting with ROT devices?
Yes. Only the host should be able to do it so, at least for now. Confirmed with some folks internal to Google.
ConfigureManager isn't limited only to the host, but sure, I guess it's fine for the moment.
Looks like this linebreak got lost so the whole commit message is on the first line now

This is a very interesting patch, thanks for writing it.

BMCweb is looking to add unit test to more then just the google specific parts.

So we are able to mock google specific calls by adding rfUtils, and hothInterfaces indirection to the GoogleServiceAsyncResp. 

Is the is the idea?
1) that google stuff is tested differently then other AsyncResp
2) or that most bmcweb responses would need a unique AsyncResp struct 
3) or that we would be able to write a general AsyncResp that would handle most responses?

I went this route to be able to add mocking support.
presumably, there is mostly no need for a GoogleServiceAsyncResp if we can add add the mockable interfaces to bmcweb::AsyncResp directly and mock them out.

I just added GoogleServiceAsyncResp because I was not sure if hothinterface is a thing for non-Google resources.
Removed unit tests for now and will revisit that in a child CL in a bid to unblock this CL.
depth can be -ve here ..? if not u can use unsigned int .
The dbus interface takes int for some reason. Keeping it that way for now.
Pretty minor changes needed, then this should be good to go.

This patch is still inventing a bunch of wrappers around generic things, which, while probably useful, deserves a discussion around how we generically access dbus, and include the other people writing handlers.  Lets do this using the existing primitives, and we can see which of these patterns work in the next patchset.

Fair enough. 

I think these wrappers are the way forward. It gives the level of indirection we would need to unit test the responses. But I can see how that is a bigger discussion, and not alighted with this features timeline.

Per cpp core guidelines (the coding standard we use) please don't forward declare methods like this.  Either rearrange your code so it's not required, or the put the prototypes in a common header that all users can rely on.

personally don't like auto for type that are unclear, but is probably okay here because this is a 
void (const crow::Request&, const std::shared_ptr<GoogleServiceAsyncResp>&, const std::string&, std::function<void( const crow::Request&, const std::shared_ptr<GoogleServiceAsyncResp>&, const ResolvedEntity&)>)
so auto is fine.

Have you thought about putting this function inline, (line 105, in the getSubTree). But is up to you
Needs a range check. possible nullptr dreference if object.second.size() is 0.

it seems really odd we have an array of bytes, and we wouldn't just return it as an array[number].  With that said, I know that was discussed, and if this is the conclusion you came to, that's fine.

FWIW, we have helper functions for this, given that boost::algorithm::hex drags a bunch of locale stuff with it that we don't want.

If this really needs to be a hex "string" instead of an array, that's fine, but we should be using the intToHexString method we do elsewhere to avoid duplicating binary code. (yes, in this case it will require a loop given that things are already a string.
same thought you might want to inline this handleFunc code, for readability. But it is up to you.

no need to wrap in lambdas for any of these.  should just be:

    BMCWEB_ROUTE(app, "/google/v1/RootOfTrustCollection/<str>")
        .privileges({{"ConfigureManager"}})
        .methods(boost::beast::http::verb::get)(
                getRootOfTrust
            );


You can construct the GoogleServiceAsyncResp as the first line of your code in those methods.
These come for free by inheriting from Resource, right?
Oop. Yes. Thanks for pointing this Ed.
Couple things that should hopefully be minor to fix, then this should be good to go.
Why is this include needed?  I don't see any uses, and there really shouldn't be anything generic in this file, if there is, it needs moved into a generic location.

Please don't capture the Request object by reference in an async callback.  This causes lifetime issues if the connection is dropped while a dbus request is in flight.

This looks like it is only captured so it can be passed to ResolvedEntityHandler, which then consequently doesn't use it, so I suspect that that passing can be removed entirely.

Ah, but request is used in case of the invokeRoTCommand handler to read the json command.

I changed the ResolvedEntityHandler to pass in a "command" instead of capturing the request and it will be empty on the /RootOfTrust/{Id} request.

That works for now without causing lifetime management issues of the request.
LMKWYT.

> Ah, but request is used in case of the invokeRoTCommand handler to read the json command.
> 
> I changed the ResolvedEntityHandler to pass in a "command" instead of capturing the request and it will be empty on the /RootOfTrust/{Id} request.

Yep, this is the correct way to do it.

> 
> That works for now without causing lifetime management issues of the request.
> LMKWYT.
You might want to log an error, but returning 16 is fine
Looks duplicated with line 1?  Does this file parse as valid xml?

it is recommended to use size_t or ssize_t for things that are sizes, counts, etc.
Refer - https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#misc-guidelines

We are dealing with nibbles here. uint8_t is the better representation for this instead of size_t, IMO.

FWIW, bytesToHexString also uses uint8_t to represent bytes.
should we support both possible capitalization of hex here?  It's a subtle compatibility thing between versions, but it's probably worth defining how we parse this very explicitly.
nit, std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max() is the more modern way to do this.
